title: How many NATO members will spend 2% or more of their GDP on defense in 2018?
preds: My mistake was forecasting the final result, not the estimates of the final report.
The House of Commons Library Briefing Paper Number CBP 8175 states "Estimates for 2018 show that only five member states have achieved the 2% target." citing NATO as a source.
Recent events - namely Trump’s comments highlight the need for more countries to spend more on NATO commitments.

4 are already there and expected to remain above 2%- Estonia, Greece, UK, US
2 are borderline and will probably exceed - Poland & Romania
2 are close and aiming to reach there - Lithuania & Latvia [a lot of what Greece is spending is on military pensions - so that tells you how meaningless this 2% target is] latest NATO doc: https://www.nato.int/nato_static_fl2014/assets/pdf/pdf_2018_03/20180315_180315-pr2018-16-en.pdf
trends: https://www.washingtonpost.com/amphtml/world/europe/trump-wants-all-of-nato-spending-2-percent-on-defense-but-does-that-even-make-sense/2018/07/10/6be06da2-7f08-11e8-a63f-7b5d2aba7ac5_story.html

The 2% figure didn't fall out of the sky at #NATO2018 or even this year. The Pentagon types have been bitching about it for a while. The countries closest to Russia really want to get good with NATO after the Crimean annexation. For them it's not just a matter of meeting an arbitrary figure; they are willing to spend to transform their militaries to keep up with really rapidly changing tech platforms such as the F-35. If everyone who's kind of close to 2% makes it, then we'd have nine.

Although Trump is making a lot of noise about this issue governments move slowly and there will be no change in 2018 in the number of countries that will spend 2% or more of their GDP in 2018. However I think in 2019 and beyond we will see an increase in the number, perhaps to 10-12 by the end of 2020.

The response of European NATO members to pressure to increase military spending towards the target of 2% of GDP, renewed and strengthened at the NATO summit in Wales in September 2014, has shown a clear regional divide. Using NATO data (which differs from SIPRI in definition for some countries, due to SIPRI including paramilitary forces), those NATO members in Central Europe (the Baltics, former Yugoslavia, and the Visegrád group) that did not already meet the 2% target, increased their military burden in 2017 by an average of .14% of GDP. Those in Western Europe did so by a mere 0.03% of GDP. Since 2014, the figure is .2% of GDP for Central Europe, and the same .03% for Western.
https://sites.tufts.edu/reinventingpeace/2018/05/02/new-sipri-figures-for-world-military-expenditure/ http://www.fmn.dk/eng/allabout/Pages/Defenceexpenditure.aspx

Poland, UK, Estonia, Greece, and USA = 5 (who all claim to be at 2% or more). Note all of these countries consistently above 2% except Poland which is committed to increasing and largest NATO cheerleader in Europe.

Romania has committed to 2% through 2026. That’s 8
Getting above 8 is more challenging... France targeting but not for 2018. Turkey increasing but not for 2018.

only base probability is calculated:
create 2 groups of countries: 
- countries without recent change in expenditures (excluding countries never close to 1.5% for simplicity) :
   - lognormal distribution assumed , to slightly overweight extreme events
   - extrapolated mean value: equal to last years mean
   - estimated sigma: sigma of recent expenditures
- countries with change (growths) in recent years (e.g. Bulgaria, Latvia, Lithuania, Romania)
   - also lognormal distro
   - extrapolate mean from linear fit of the years since the change accord
   - calculate sigma from years before the change occurred 
Use Monte-Carlo-Sim of all lognormal distributed probabilities.
drawbacks: 
- No recent information used: change (growths) identified by change in recent years . 2018 events not considered et all.
- reason for change not identified: only the outcome is extrapolated: If the reason vanished , high expenditures everestimated.
- lognormal distribution only heavy tailed for large numbers of countries. But reduced number of countries in my feeling does not represent the Zeitgeist und the 7% for <5 seems OK for representing the risk of fast change in Zeitgeist.
you can find a more detailed essay here: https://www.dropbox.com/s/qkr2lg86082hlix/444_Summary.pdf?dl=0 .

According to the theory of offense-defense balance, several European states in NATO will up their defense spending. As Russia increases hostilities on the outskirts of Europe, seen in their activity in Crimea and the Baltic states, the rest of Europe will find itself in an offense-dominant space and feel the need to better 'defend' themselves.

NATO reported 2017 numbers with only 4 members making >=2% of GDP.  Poland was just under, at 1.99%.  Given the pressure by the Trump administration for NATO members to increase their spending, the recklessness and unpredictability of Russia, and the vulnerability of particular neighboring states, you would expect them to demonstrate the importance of the alliance by increasing their military spending.  Poland, Lithuania, and Latvia have all expressed intent to reach or exceed the 2% figure in the near future, but it's uncertain whether they will in 2018, although Poland seems pretty likely to.  There seems a reasonable chance that Romania will finish over.  France is close, but is still operating on a 5 year defense budget that ends in 2018, with big increases voted in for 2019-2024, so I rate their chance of hitting the 2% target as basically 0%.  https://www.defensenews.com/global/europe/2018/02/08/france-proposes-big-defense-budget-hike/

I finally got around to manipulating the data and it's pretty interesting.  If you take the 2017 estimates and add the MAXIMUM positive delta, you have the usual 5 countries (US, UK, Estonia, Greece and Poland) but add Lithuania, Latvia and Romania for a total of 8.   On the other hand if you take the 2017 estimates and add the AVERAGE positive delta, you only have the usual 5 countries.   So Latvia, Lithuania and Romania are the only three countries that are close enough to the 2% and have historically increased their budgets by enough to be able to hit the target.  There are outside chances that France could make a 0.21% increase but those chances are equally likely that Latvia, Lithuania or Romania do not hit the 2.0% target.

The big question is between 5-8, with Latvia, Romania, and Lithuanian having the biggest increases from 2016-2017 and the closes to crossing the 2% threshold. If all three did, then you have 8. France and Norway are also close but they have low YoY increases. I see Latvia and Lithuania due to Russia proximity as potentials. But Romania only needs .2% increase in 2018 to get there. If Latvia and Lithuania continue their YoY increase then they will get close slightly over. So the real question that would put me in the 6-8 inclusive is, what do I think the probability that at least one of the 3 will get there. With all the stuff with Russia and expelling the diplomats I would say at least 70% chance.
I've been treating the probabilities of each country meeting the target as independent, but they're not.

There are a number of dynamic factors facing the number of European countries that will meet the 2% spending goal. More than enough countries are on track for increasing their net spending, however growth of their GDP's may outpace the growth of their defense spending resulting in failure to increase to the 2% goal. According the NATO releases there are eight countries currently at or above the 2% mark: U.S., U.K., Greece, Poland, Latvia, Estonia, Romania and Lithuania . However, Romania and Poland are of such a thin margin that they are likely to drop below 2% as their GDPs benefit from positive economic trends across Europe during the course of 2018 leaving the total at a likely 7 allowing for any one of several bubble countries reaching the 2% mark by the end of the year.

The IHS Markit's Jane's Defense budgets report forecasts nine NATO countries to spend 2 percent or more in 2018 which include: Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, the U.S., the U.K., Turkey, Poland, Romania and Greece.  In 2016, Latvia, Lithuania, Romania and Turkey spent under the 2 percent goal.  In 2017, Romania was the only country from the previous group in 2016 to surpass the 2 percent mark.  With that said, Latvia and Lithuania have made significant increases toward reaching the 2 percent goal in the last few years.  There is a chance however that GDP growth in countries such as Romania and Poland might actually result in falling short of 2 percent defense spending.  Looking at different scenarios, it is likely that Estonia, the U.S., U.K. and Greece will certainly spend 2 percent.  There is a scenario involving Romania and Poland GDP growth pushing them under the 2 percent but this would be offset by Latvia and Lithuania making for at least six, potentially eight with Turkey as the kicker.  Finally, since 2014, in response to Russia’s annexation of Ukraine’s Crimea region, a majority of NATO members have put in place a plan to reach the 2 percent goal by 2024.  For this reason, future projections assume a majority of countries are working towards increasing their share rather than looking to decrease spending.

Last publication has 6 countries spending 2%. Of the 6, 2 countries (Romania and Poland) are near the cutoff level, at 2.02 and 2.01 respectively. Although both countries are increasing spending and express an intent to maintain 2%, both are also experiencing gdp growth. There is a reasonable chance that at least one of the two, if not both, will still fall slightly short of 2% as a result of growth outpacing spending increases. At the same time, it seems unlikely that sufficient additional countries will radically increase spending to make the cutoff this year, although several intend to do so over a 5-year period.

In Lithuania, where I spent the most time (5 weeks), there is a sense of fear, but also that they really can't do anything about their powerful neighbor if they wanted to. Not to mention, many of them don't even care and are just living life day to day and would continue life as they have it either way.    They would just assume be occupied by Russian forces as with Nato. As long as they can still drink bear and vodka and watch soccer in the local pubs and make love to their wives.  I got the sense that the women are more likely to lean to the west as they've done better with a more western economy, maybe that is skewed because I am western man was talking to them indicting that they are looking to the west. Many men I met seems to actually be happier in the past when they were the bread winners in a more traditional eastern household. Many men seems conflicted, they don't want to return to a military state, but seem quite frustrated with liberal western values and with western men and all their money who come in a give their women rings and better jobs.   Meanwhile, the brain drain continues, many smart youth leave. While many avg Joes sitting in pubs watching sport complaining remain.  That type don't have a problem with Putin's right wing crack downs, and see him as a sort of hero to masculinity, they know the west is better with human rights, but they'd just assume have slave labor at home. Same was true in Romania when I was there a couple years ago two times.  Ukraine was different, they obviously have big problem with Russia, but at the same time don't fully trust the west has their best intentions in mind.   All these Eastern Europeans make less than $1000 a month on average and work their asses off. So I say it will remain the nearly same, for now, with spending increases coming very slightly as their economies and cultures continue to merge with the west.

The critical point is "in 2018", which is a very short time to make the huge budget increases necessary. The NATO guideline is that 20% of expenditure should be on equipment, which is fairly easy to increase (if the will exists). but even doubling the amount that most NATO countries spend on equipment would only increase their total spend by 7% to 15% which is a long way short of getting them up to 2% of GDP. As personnel costs include pensions under the NATO definition even increasing the numbers of serving personnel has less effect of percentage personnel costs as it first appears (i.e. salary costs of current employees would increase, but pension costs would not). Unless there is an obvious immediate danger (as there is in the Baltic countries) NATO is more likely to continue to expect to see progress on increasing expenditure towards the 2% figure in a 5 or 6 year time frame than insisting on hitting the 2% figure by next year and having much of the extra money spent on untrained personnel and/or unsuitable equipment.

5 Countries spent the target 2% of GDP on defense in 2016. Over the last few years more countries have accepted that they need to spend more to meet their NATO obligations and the arrival of Trump has probably concentrated minds on the need, but defense spending is not something that its easy to turn on and off in two years. I suppose countries could order some expensive weapons system in order to hit the target, but its unlikely that that would produce effective extra defense capabilities in just two years. Expanding facilities, training personnel, equipment delivery times all make ramping up defense spending difficult. Doing so when many governments are still pursuing spending reductions in other areas will be politically difficult. 
There are a few countries (e.g. Baltic States) that are not that far off the 2% target, but several that if they see the need could adopt some creative accounting to hit the target. (As German has pointed out where does peace keeping expenditure end and defense expenditure start;  lots of countries could probably claim that cyber security was part of defense, and maybe some police expenditure, and what about dual use airports, ports, planes, ships, hospitals etc.)

With Trump threatening to get out of NATO and the recent visit of Pence, the VP, in which he insisted that NATO members meet their financial obligations, all European NATO members are afraid that the US will walk out from NATO and leave them exposed to Russian threats and intimidation.

Seeing more countries increase their budget to 2% sounds intuitively possible, but if you look at the budget statements from most of the countries you'll find they're only considering moderate increases. Reaching 2% is a large percentage increase and a lot of money for most of them when many are still constrained budget-wise.
Increased fear of Russia slightly overcompensates for those who might drop for economic or political reasons.
